Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Investigation of RNA Unwinding And Ribosomal Frameshifting

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: The ribosome is a large, macromolecular machine found in all organisms that primarily functions to produce protein. This process, referred to as translation, is very complex and highly regulated with many accessory factors that facilitate efficient protein production. In normal translation, the ribosome translates a message by interpreting three positions on the message (RNA) into one amino acid. By advancing three positions at a time, the ribosome continues to build the protein sequence until a specific sequence on the message known as a stop codon is encountered at which point the full length protein is released from the ribosome. Often, complex three dimensional structures are present within the message and must be unwound for translation to continue. In some cases, these structures can induce the ribosome to slip back one position. This causes the ribosome to be in a different frame or frameshift and will cause the ribosome to skip over the stop codon that would have been encountered in the original frame generally producing a longer protein sequence. While much is known about frameshifting, there are still important questions that remain to be addressed in detail. In this project, the following questions related to frameshifting will be addressed by employing advanced biophysical techniques. First, the mechanism by which the ribosome unwinds complex three dimensional structures within the message in order to continue translation will be elucidated. Second, how these structures influence the global and local motions within the ribosome will be investigated. Finally, why some structures have a greater propensity to induce frameshifting than others by probing the inherent dynamic motions of a subset of structures that vary in frameshifting efficiency will be investigated. These experiments will provide a comprehensive description of unwinding and lead to a greater description of the process of frameshifting. Further, these experiments will have a profound impact on the ribosome and biophysics fields as well as a general impact on the scientific community particularly at the University of Missouri by pushing the limits and capabilities of biophysical techniques.

Broader Impact: With only 5.5% of the population in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) in the United States, it is essential that education and awareness is emphasized for both the general public and in our public schools and higher education institutions. A committment to develop and implement several specific activities that will have a direct and immediate impact in several areas with a special emphasis on underrepresented and lower income populations has been made. Education and outreach activities include: to assist with an MU teacher training program intended for grades K-8; to develop new curricula to expand the teacher training program to include high school teachers in chemistry and biochemistry with the intention of integrating cutting edge science into the classroom; to provide undergraduate research opportunities to high achieving students and to minority students preparing them for careers in STEM; to continue mentoring graduate students and encourage outreach activities; to engage in public speaking opportunities in the immediate area as well as in Universities with minimal research opportunities; and to develop undergraduate and graduate level course material that will challenge and provide hands on experience in scientific research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit outcomes and findings

The synthesis of proteins is accomplished through a highly coordinated process.  The central component required for the production of all proteins is the ribosome.  The ribosome deciphers the genetic code brought to it by a transient molecule of messenger RNA (mRNA).  Composed of two subunits the ribosome binds to a series of accessory factors that direct protein synthesis by altering the conformation of the ribosome by specifically changing the orientation between the two subunits.  In our laboratory, we study protein synthesis using a highly sophisticated fluorescence microscopy approach to directly monitor changes in distance in real time.  By attaching fluorescent molecules one to each subunit, we can infer an alteration in the angle of rotation between the subunits and thus determine which global conformational state the ribosome is in.  During normal protein synthesis, the ribosomal subunits primarily inhabit two conformational states generally referred to as the rotated and non-rotated state.  In many instances, sequences within the mRNA and other factors can influence translation resulting in alternate outcomes.  The fundamental objective for our research program during the funding period was to investigate various non-canonical translation mechanisms. Our central hypothesis was that the conformational dynamics of the ribosome are integrally linked to its function. Hence, a more comprehensive understanding of translation will emerge, as we understand how minor alterations in protein synthesis change ribosome motion.  

Ribosomal frameshifting is an aberrant process in protein synthesis that results in a different protein product.  Since the ribosome reads the mRNA three bases at a time, a simple shift on the mRNA by a single base results in the ribosome reading the message differently from that point on.  In many cases, this frameshift results in part because of folded structures within the mRNA.  The prevailing model is that the RNA structures function as a roadblock to normal protein synthesis, which need to be unfolded for translation to continue often resulting in a single base shift in reading frame.  As the ribosome has been shown to unfold structures within the RNA by itself, we endeavored to investigate how unwinding of RNA structures by the ribosome changes the conformational dynamics of the two ribosomal subunits.  In one series of experiments, we chose a sequence derived from the DNA polymerase gene from Escherichia colithat induces high levels of frameshifting.  By placing the mRNA structure that causes frameshifting just outside the entry tunnel of the ribosome, we were able to directly observe changes in the conformational dynamics of the ribosome.  The main finding from these studies is that structured mRNA induces the ribosome into a third conformational state we called the hyper-rotated state.  In addition to this hyper-rotation, the ribosome stalled and was no longer as conformationally flexible as compared to mRNA sequences that lacked structured sequences.  To pinpoint, at what distance between the ribosome and the mRNA structure was necessary to result in hyper-rotation a series of experiments were performed, which showed that positioning of the mRNA structure six to eight bases from the decoding center was necessary to induce hyper-rotation.  Further experiments established how stable RNA structures need to be to induce hyper-rotation and additional experiments are underway to correlate our findings with the process of frameshifting.

A separate line of experiments developed during our funding period, which involved investigating the result of truncated mRNA on the conformational state of the ribosome and rescue by alternate release factor B (ArfB or YaeJ).  We found that, similar to the standard release factors, YaeJ stabilizes the ribosome in the non-rotated state setting the stage for termination of protein synthesis and ribosome recycling.  Interestingly, when the mRNA was shortened up to the decoding center, we observed that the ribosome entered the hyper-rotated state similar to what was observed with structured mRNA sequences.  Follow up experiments are ongoing to investigate this aspect in greater detail.

 

Broader impacts outcomes and findings

The primary theme for the broader impacts emphasis of our research program was to provide high school teachers and students with the opportunity to experience science at a higher level than was experienced at high school.  The goal was to bridge the gap scientifically between high school and college/university.  An accessory goal was to encourage students to be involved in research while at college/university.  To facilitate this, I along with Renee Jiji (Chemistry) organized a two-week science camp each summer in chemistry and biochemistry.  In the first week of the camp, we prepared lessons that contained a laboratory component in both fields and taught them to a small group of high school educators (~2-4).  In the second week, the same teachers turned around and taught the lessons learned in week one to a group of high school juniors and seniors (~8-36).  Our program was very successful and highlighted both by the University of Missouri and the NSF.
